frontmatter.title: ASTR 596: Artificial Intelligence Policy and Learning Framework

children.value: Course Philosophy: AI as a Performance Amplifier, Not a Substitute

children.label: Course Philosophy: AI as a Performance Amplifier, Not a Substitute

children.value: : AI tools are transforming scientific computing and research. As future astrophysicists, you will work in an AI-integrated environment where these tools are standard professional practice.
Recent MIT research suggests that heavy AI reliance weakens cognitive development.

Students who used ChatGPT showed weaker neural connectivity and couldn’t remember what they’d just “written.” AI raises the bar for human capability—it amplifies what we expect you to accomplish and understand, but only if you use it strategically.
: This course treats AI as a
for competent practitioners, not as a substitute for learning. You must first develop core competencies through productive struggle, then learn to use AI strategically to enhance your capabilities.
: Ting & O’Briain (2025) found that students who used structured AI integration with documentation requirements
actually decreased their AI dependence over time
while developing stronger problem-solving skills and AI literacy. This contradicts common fears about AI creating academic dependency.
: Learning requires intellectual risk-taking, exploration, and yes, making mistakes.
The struggle is where cognitive growth happens.
This policy is designed to support genuine learning while building your capacity to work effectively with AI throughout your career.
How to Cite AI Usage in Your Code

children.label: How to Cite AI Usage in Your Code

children.value: When AI assists with your code, document it clearly:

# AI-assisted: ChatGPT helped optimize this nested loop structure
# Verified against NumPy documentation: https://numpy.org/doc/stable/reference/generated/numpy.vectorize.html
# Original approach used nested for loops, AI suggested vectorization
def calculate_distances(positions):
    # Implementation here
    pass

# Debugging with Claude: Identified index out of bounds error in original implementation
# Solution verified by testing edge cases [0, 1, n-1, n]
def get_neighbors(grid, i, j):
    # Implementation here
    pass

## AI Usage Documentation

**Conceptual Understanding**: Used ChatGPT to clarify difference between Euler and RK4 stability 
regions after reading Numerical Recipes Ch. 17.1. Verified understanding by implementing both 
and comparing error accumulation.

**Debugging Assistance**: Claude helped identify memory leak in particle array allocation. 
Solution involved properly clearing arrays between iterations (lines 145-150).

**Not AI-Generated**: Core algorithm implementation, physics calculations, and analysis 
were completed independently following course materials.
: Use official documentation, textbooks, and manual implementation
: Spend at least 20-30 minutes wrestling with problems using only your mind before consulting AI
: All AI interactions must include links to relevant official documentation
: Building neural pathways and pattern recognition that AI cannot provide—this is where cognitive growth happens
: Study matplotlib documentation → understand Figure/Axes hierarchy → attempt implementation → struggle with specific issues → document your thinking → use AI to debug specific errors
: Ask AI “how to make a scatter plot” without first attempting to understand the underlying concepts
: AI can be used for efficiency
: Must cross-reference AI suggestions with official sources
: Must explain why AI suggestions are appropriate/inappropriate
: “I need to add a legend. I’ll check matplotlib.pyplot.legend documentation first to understand all options, then use AI to help me implement the specific styling I want.”
: Ask AI “add legend to plot” and copy-paste the first solution without understanding alternatives or parameters
AI as Productivity Tool for Competent Practitioners
: You now have foundation knowledge to evaluate AI suggestions critically
: AI can be used for acceleration, exploration, and complex problem-solving
: AI-assisted work must meet higher standards than manual work
: Continue citing AI usage and verification sources
AI Usage Documentation in Growth Memos

children.label: AI Usage Documentation in Growth Memos

children.value: Rather than weekly summaries, document your AI usage in each Growth Memo (due after each project):
: Describe 2-3 substantial uses of AI tools for that project
: For each interaction, link to the primary sources you consulted
: What did you learn about effective AI usage? What didn’t work?
: How did your AI usage align with the current phase expectations?
Portfolio Approach (Part of Technical Growth Synthesis)

children.label: Portfolio Approach (Part of Technical Growth Synthesis)

children.value: Your final Technical Growth Synthesis (due Dec 11) should include an AI literacy portfolio section demonstrating:
: 3-4 well-documented AI interactions from across the semester showing your growth
: How your AI strategies evolved from Phase 1 to Phase 3
: Specific examples where AI helped and where it hindered learning
: Reflection on how you’ll use AI in future research/industry work
: Asking AI to solve entire assignment problems
: Using AI to bypass understanding fundamental concepts
: Using AI code without understanding or verification
: Using AI instead of reading official documentation
: “Don’t solve this for me, but help me understand what questions I should be asking”
: After independent troubleshooting attempts and documentation consultation
: After implementing working solutions manually to understand the core concepts
: “Here’s my approach and where I’m stuck. What’s a different mental model I could use?”
: “I’m working on problems A, B, and C. What underlying principle connects them?”
without understanding and rewriting in your own style
: After AI assistance, close the conversation and summarize key insights from memory
: Be able to explain AI suggestions to a classmate in your own words
Each Growth Memo (submitted Wednesdays after project completion) should include an AI usage section (~1 paragraph) addressing:
: How did the 20-minute struggle rule affect your learning? What did you gain from avoiding immediate AI assistance?
: Describe your debugging process. How did documentation-first help before using AI?
: Compare solving problems with and without AI. What patterns do you notice?
: How has AI helped or hindered your understanding of Monte Carlo methods?
: Describe a time when AI gave incorrect advice. How did you identify and correct it?
: How has your AI strategy evolved since Week 1? What’s your professional approach going forward?
Throughout the course, expect informal check-ins where I may:
: “Walk me through why you chose this approach”
: “What happens if we change this parameter?”
: “How does this relate to what we learned in Project 2?”

These conversations help ensure you understand your implementations and can think critically about your code. This is supportive, not punitive—it’s about reinforcing learning and catching confusion early.
: Professional developers must understand their tools deeply enough to debug, optimize, and adapt AI suggestions
: Scientific computing requires understanding trade-offs, limitations, and edge cases that AI may not address
: Practitioners who understand fundamentals adapt to new tools; those who don’t become obsolete
: In research, you must be able to verify and defend every aspect of your computational work
: You should be capable of solving problems manually, consulting documentation, and implementing solutions from first principles
: You should accomplish significantly more complex problems, higher quality implementations, and deeper exploration of edge cases
: AI amplifies your capabilities without replacing your critical thinking
: Read course materials on MCMC theory and Metropolis-Hastings algorithm
: Study NumPy random module documentation for sampling functions
: Code basic Metropolis-Hastings from mathematical principles
: “I’ve implemented basic MCMC. Can you help me optimize the proposal distribution tuning based on my current acceptance rate calculation?”
: Cross-reference AI suggestions with statistical computing literature
: “Write me a Metropolis-Hastings algorithm for parameter estimation”
: Use AI code without understanding acceptance criteria or proposal distributions
: Never consult course materials or statistical references
This AI integration policy is a

that allows you to use cutting-edge tools while learning. This privilege comes with strict responsibility for honest, ethical usage. Abuse of this policy violates both course standards and SDSU’s academic integrity policies.
The following constitute academic dishonesty under SDSU policies:
Submitting AI-generated work without proper citation
Using AI to complete assignments without demonstrating personal understanding
Claiming AI-assisted work as entirely your own creation
Copying AI responses without verification or comprehension
Having AI solve entire homework problems without independent work
Using AI to write reports/memos without engaging with the material personally
Submitting code you cannot explain or debug independently
Violating phase-specific AI restrictions (e.g., using AI for primary learning in Phases 1-2)
This course’s AI policy operates within SDSU’s academic integrity framework:
: All AI usage must be transparent and documented
: Students are trusted to follow scaffolding guidelines; violations break this trust
: Equal access to AI tools with equal responsibility for learning outcomes
: Respect for the learning process and instructor expectations
: Personal accountability for understanding and competency development
: Mandatory office hours meeting to discuss AI usage strategy
: Zero credit for assignment, no resubmission opportunity
: Reported to Office of Student Rights and Responsibilities per SDSU Student Conduct Code
: May result in formal academic integrity violation on transcript
: May result in course failure depending on violation severity
: Course failure regardless of other performance
: Full academic integrity investigation per SDSU procedures
: Complete prohibition from AI tool usage for remainder of course
: AI misuse identified through code analysis, plagiarism detection, or student inability to explain submitted work
: Detailed record of violation with evidence
: Mandatory meeting to discuss violation and consequences
: Violations reported to appropriate university offices per SDSU Student Conduct Code Section 41301
: Students may appeal through standard SDSU academic grievance procedures
: Research careers require absolute integrity in computational work
: AI dependency prevents mastery of essential skills
: Students following the policy deserve recognition for their legitimate effort
: Graduate programs and employers rely on SDSU’s academic standards
Bring specific questions about your thinking process
Come prepared to explain what you’ve tried
Expect guided questions that help you discover solutions
AI strategy consultations are always welcome
: Share AI strategies with your partner
: Brief class discussions about effective AI usage
: Celebrate interesting discoveries and productive failures
: For conceptual explanations and debugging assistance (use in browser/app, not IDE)
: For research with automatic source citation
: For creating study guides from course materials
: GitHub Copilot and all IDE AI assistants remain disabled throughout the semester per syllabus policy
: Prefer specialized tools for astronomy/physics questions
: Use for programming syntax and debugging
: Cross-reference between different AI tools and documentation
: Always verify AI responses with instructor/peers/documentation

AI is a powerful tool that amplifies human intelligence and capability. It does not replace the need for deep understanding, critical thinking, or foundational knowledge. Students who master both fundamental competencies AND strategic AI usage will thrive. Those who attempt to substitute AI for learning will fail to meet the elevated standards that AI-augmented practice demands.

Your goal is not just to complete assignments, but to become a computational astrophysicist capable of tackling novel research problems with both traditional methods and cutting-edge AI tools. This requires mastering both domains.
